questions.question_text:
While researching coastal erosion management, a student has taken the following notes: - A 2018–2023 comparative study examined 14 coastal municipalities. - Towns that prohibited seawalls and funded dune restoration saw a 30% reduction in average shoreline retreat relative to similar towns that permitted seawalls. - Seawalls protected adjacent properties in the short term but increased erosion downstream. - In prohibition towns, tourism revenue rose by 12% on average, attributed to wider beaches. - Nature-based strategies had higher maintenance costs in the first two years but lower costs thereafter. - The study’s policy brief concluded that nature-based approaches delivered net long-term benefits.
The student wants to make and support a generalization about the long-term outcomes of nature-based approaches compared with seawalls. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching an upcoming space telescope mission, a student has taken the following notes: - The ORBIT-2 mission (launch planned for 2027) will focus on planets orbiting M-dwarf stars. - Its near-infrared spectrometer is optimized to detect water vapor absorption features. - Target sample: 60 exoplanets, primarily close-in, temperate worlds. - The team will compare water signature strength while accounting for stellar flares and activity indices. - Hypothesis: some close-in exoplanets retain atmospheric water despite high stellar activity.
The student wants to present the primary aim of the mission. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching medieval European guilds, a student has taken the following notes: - In 14th-century Flanders, textile guilds controlled apprenticeship pipelines and enforced quality standards. - Archival wage records indicate that guild towns paid higher average wages than comparable non-guild towns. - Non-guild cities adopted mechanized fulling and new looms earlier, raising output per worker by the late 1300s. - Export prices for guild-certified cloth were consistently higher, attributed to reputation for quality. - An economic historian concludes that guilds traded productive efficiency for credible quality signaling.
The student wants to articulate the study’s central trade-off. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching a county vaccination initiative, a student has taken the following notes: - In 2021–2022, the county ran mobile clinics plus texting outreach in five neighborhoods with the lowest vaccination rates. - Target-area vaccination rates rose from 48% to 71%; in matched control neighborhoods without the program, rates rose from 52% to 58%. - Post-visit surveys: most appointments in target areas were scheduled via text links. - Estimated program cost per additional vaccination: 34 dollars. - Uptake gains plateaued after about four months.
The student wants to summarize the program’s effectiveness while acknowledging a key limitation. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching bilingual code-switching, a student has taken the following notes: - A corpus study examined Spanish–English bilinguals across professional emails and casual text messages. - Intra-sentential switching rate: 3% in professional emails vs. 22% in casual texts. - Common functions of switches in texts: introducing culturally specific terms; signaling stance or emphasis. - Interviewees reported avoiding switches in formal contexts due to professionalism norms. - A linguist argues code-switching is pragmatic rather than random.
The student wants to describe what the data suggest about the function of code-switching. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching marine protected areas, a student has taken the following notes: - A decade-long study compared no-take reserves with adjacent fished areas. - Inside reserves, biomass increased by approximately 250% across target species. - In adjacent fished zones, catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) rose by about 20% after year 5. - CPUE gains were not observed for highly mobile pelagic species. - Habitat complexity was a positive predictor of spillover magnitude. - Authors conclude reserves can enhance local fisheries when species are relatively sedentary and habitats are complex.
The student wants to explain under what conditions the reserves benefited nearby fisheries. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching approaches to AI regulation, a student has taken the following notes: - A 2025 policy paper compares risk-based regulation (e.g., EU model) and sectoral enforcement (e.g., US model). - Risk-based systems classify applications by risk tier and impose stricter requirements on high-risk uses. - Sectoral enforcement relies on existing agencies within domains like health or finance. - Case studies: medical diagnostic AI showed stronger safety compliance under risk-based rules; fintech AI deployed faster under sectoral oversight with similar consumer complaint rates. - The paper argues no single model dominates across domains and proposes a blended strategy.
The student wants to present the paper’s recommendation grounded in its comparative findings. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching vertical farming, a student has taken the following notes: - Vertical farms use up to 95% less land and water than conventional farming. - Electricity demand for lighting and climate control is high and can dominate environmental impacts. - Life-cycle assessment (LCA): in coal-heavy grids, vertical-farm lettuce has roughly twice the emissions of field-grown; in renewable-heavy grids, emissions are about 40% lower than field-grown. - Product quality and yields are consistent year-round.
The student wants to convey the main conditional finding about environmental impact. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching labor and recognition in the construction of a transcontinental railroad, a student has taken the following notes: - The workforce included Chinese and Irish immigrants, Black freedmen, and Mesoamerican laborers. - Payroll and accident reports show Chinese crews received lower wages and had higher fatality rates in mountain sections. - Contemporary political speeches credited "American ingenuity" while largely omitting immigrant labor. - Early 20th-century commemorations began to acknowledge multiple groups. - A historian argues that public narratives initially erased immigrant contributions despite material reliance on their labor.
The student wants to make and support a claim about the discrepancy between contribution and recognition. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

While researching the cognitive effects of sleep deprivation, a student has taken the following notes: - Double-blind, within-subjects design with 40 adults: one night of total sleep deprivation vs. normal sleep. - Tasks assessed sustained attention, working memory, and emotion recognition. - Performance changes after sleep deprivation: sustained attention declined by about 35%; working memory by about 15%; emotion recognition showed no significant change. - Caffeine improved sustained attention by roughly half of the observed deficit but did not eliminate working-memory declines. - Authors caution against claims of global cognitive impairment; effects vary by domain.
The student wants to state the qualified conclusion drawn by the authors. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.label: Seawalls protected adjacent properties and increased erosion downstream, showing why they should be banned.
Tourism revenue rose in towns that banned seawalls, although maintenance costs were higher.
The study found that both seawalls and dune restoration reduced shoreline retreat by similar amounts, but for different reasons.

Across the municipalities studied, prohibiting seawalls and investing in dune restoration yielded better long-term results—slower shoreline retreat and higher tourism revenue—despite higher early maintenance costs.
The ORBIT-2 mission primarily aims to determine whether close-in exoplanets around M-dwarfs retain atmospheric water by mapping water vapor with near-infrared spectroscopy.
Using a near-infrared spectrometer, the mission will observe 60 exoplanets and compare water signatures with stellar activity indices.
Because flares can strip atmospheres, the team expects to find little water vapor around most M-dwarf planets.
M-dwarfs are small stars, so their planets are easier to study than those around Sun-like stars.
Guild-controlled towns earned higher wages and higher output by adopting mechanized fulling early.
Because export prices were higher for guild-certified cloth, guilds clearly improved efficiency.
Guild regulation traded speed and efficiency for quality signaling: wages were higher and reputation supported price premiums, but adoption of new looms lagged.
Cities without strict guilds delayed mechanization, which reduced their per-worker output in the late 1300s.
Vaccination rates increased in the county from 2021 to 2022 due to broader trends and local programs.

The mobile clinics plus texting campaign produced substantially larger gains in the target neighborhoods than in controls at a cost of 34 dollars per additional shot, though uptake plateaued after four months.
Text messages scheduled most appointments, proving that texting alone caused the increase.
Although the program had a low cost per additional vaccination, the overall county rate changes were similar across neighborhoods.
Code-switching occurred at equal rates in professional and casual contexts, showing it is random.
Interview responses were the primary evidence that code-switching is perceived as professional in formal emails.
Because switches introduce culturally specific terms, they always signal a change in topic.
The corpus and interviews indicate that code-switching is a pragmatic, context-sensitive choice—common in casual messages to convey culture or stance and avoided in formal settings.
Marine reserves uniformly raised catches for all species after five years.
Habitat complexity inside reserves increased biomass by 250%.
Reserves tended to boost nearby fisheries only when target species were relatively sedentary and habitats were complex, with catch rates rising in adjacent zones after several years.
Because pelagic species benefited most, reserves are best placed in open-water areas.
Risk-based regulation outperformed sectoral enforcement in both safety and deployment speed, so it should be adopted wholesale.
Drawing on mixed case-study results, the paper recommends a hybrid approach: apply risk-tiered rules to safety-critical systems and rely on sectoral enforcement elsewhere.
Sectoral enforcement produced the fewest consumer complaints in fintech and medicine, proving it is superior.
Because the EU and US use different models, international harmonization is impossible.
The life-cycle analysis shows vertical farming's emissions advantage depends on the electricity mix: it outperforms fields on renewable-heavy grids but fares worse on fossil-heavy ones.
Vertical farms always have lower emissions than conventional farms because they use less land and water.
Year-round product consistency makes vertical farms the most sustainable option regardless of the grid's composition.
Lighting and climate control raise energy use, but the effect on emissions is negligible compared with transport.
All groups received equal pay and recognition for their work on the railroad.
Because later commemorations recognized immigrant workers, early narratives were accurate.
Material records reveal heavy reliance on immigrant labor—especially Chinese crews who faced lower wages and higher fatalities—yet early public narratives minimized these contributions.
The railroad was built mostly by engineers using machines rather than by laborers.
After one night without sleep, all measured cognitive abilities declined equally, and caffeine restored performance across the board.

The authors conclude that sleep loss produces domain-specific impairments—especially in sustained attention—while working memory and emotion recognition are less affected, and caffeine only partly offsets attention deficits.
Because emotion recognition did not change, sleep deprivation has no measurable cognitive impact.
The within-subjects design prevents any conclusions about attention.
